If a global section a of \mathrm {R} ^n f_* \mathbb {C} is of Hodge degree (p,q) at a point, then a is everywhere of degree (p,q). We will show that we are either in case (a) or case (b) of , for every place of Z simultaneously. This is clear () under the hypothesis (c.1), and follows from under the hypotheses (c.2) or (c.3), since not only \varepsilon _T, but also \varepsilon _{H \rho }, is then independent of \rho.

Condition (b) of cannot be satisfied at every place of Z, since the Hodge structure would then be locally constant, which (by and ) contradicts (b). Condition (a) is thus satisfied at each place of Z, and so H is of degree (0,0) (). Taking into account, this finishes the proof.
